review.title: SAT as a game
review.abstract: We propose a funny representation of SAT. While the primary interest is to present propositional satisfiability in a playful way for pedagogical purposes, it could also inspire new search heuristics.

metadata.title: SAT as a game

sections.heading: 1 The colored tokens game
sections.text: The board consists of boxes of round and square tiles of different colors. For each color, the player must remove either all square tiles or all round tiles. The game is won if there is at least one tile in each box. The result is the same, regardless of the order in which the tiles are removed. It depends only on the shape that is removed for each color.Figure 1: A game example. The original configuration (boxes and tiles) should be an example of the game. It is said that it is feasible if and only if it allows at least one solution.ar Xiv: 151 1.00 813v 1 [cs.C] 3N ov2 015

sections.heading: 2 SAT representation
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 SAT
sections.text: In the context of propositional logic, a literal is either a propositional variable v or its negation ¬ v, a proposition is a disjunction of the words l1, and a CNF formula is a combination of the propositions q1, q1, qn, and qn. An interpretation of a formula is the assignment of a truth value (true or false) to each variable that occurs in Σ. An interpretation is to satisfy a formula if and only if it considers this formula true according to the standard semantics of operators. A formula is to be satisfactory if and only if at least one interpretation exists that satisfies it. SAT is the problem of determining whether a given CNF formula is satisfactory or not. For more information, see for example [1].

sections.heading: 2.2 Representing a SAT instance with the colored tokens game
sections.text: Each square character represents a positive letter and each round character a negative letter. For example, the following formula encodes the original configuration of Figure 1. The variable r stands for the color red, b for blue, p for purple, and y for yellow. (r-b-p) (r-b-p) (r-b-p) (r-b-p) (r-b-p) (r-b-y) (r-y) (b-y) (b-c) Obviously, any interpretation that satisfies the resulting formula (if applicable) corresponds to a solution of the underlying game substance.

sections.heading: 3 A variant
sections.text: Here is a variant of the game based on alternative rules: the player removes one tile after another and can remove either a square or a round tile of any suit. The game ends when each box contains exactly one tile. The player wins if and only if all pieces of each suit have the same shape. SAT reduces itself in this variant in the same way as to the original game.Suggestion 1. Any instance of the variant is feasible if and only if the corresponding instance of the original game.Sketch of the toy 1. Any solution of the variant can be obtained from a solution of the original problem by removing all pieces except one from each box.2. If there is a solution sv of the variant, a solution of the original game can be obtained in the following way: from the initial state, for each color, the pieces of the form occurring in sv are retained and the others are removed.

sections.heading: 4 Interests of the game and related works
sections.text: In the literature, there are several examples of linkages between SAT and games. For example, SAT codes for the popular sudoku game were presented in [3] and [2]. Conversely, the famous Candy Crush game proved to be NP-hard thanks to a reduction in SAT in [4]. There is also a web application, "The SAT game" by Olivier Roussel (CRIL universite � d'Artois), which proposes to solve a SAT instance as an integer matrix in which every line is a clause. Variables and literals are represented by integers in the same way as in the widely used DIMACS format. The aim of the colored token representation is to make it easier for people to grasp. It could be used for vulgarising the meaningfulness, but also to analyze the strategies of the best players and to use them in designing new search criteria or branched rules.

For each color, the player must remove either all the square tokens or all the round ones. The game is won if there is at least one token in each box. The result is the same regardless of the order in which the tokens are removed. It depends only on the shape removed for each color. Figure 1: An example of game play. The initial configuration (boxes and tokens) is said to be an instance of the game. An interpretation of a formula Σ is an assignment of a truth value (true or false) to each variable occurring in Σ. An interpretation is said to satisfy a formula Σ if and only if it evaluates this formula to true according to the standard semantic of the operators ¬,∨,∧. A formula is said to be satisfiable if and only if there exists at least one interpretation that satisfies it. SAT is the problem of determining whether a given CNF formula is satisfiable or not. For more information, see, for example [1]. 2.2 Representing a SAT instance with the colored tokens game SAT reduces to the colored tokens game as follows. Each box corresponds to a clause and each color corresponds to a variable. Any square token represents a positive literal, and any round token represents a negative literal. For example, the following formula encodes the initial configuration of the figure 1. The variable r stands for the color red, b for blue, p for purple, and y for yellow, respectively. (r ∨ b ∨ ¬p) ∧ (¬r ∨ b ∨ ¬p) ∧ (r ∨ ¬b ∨ ¬p) ∧ (¬r ∨ ¬b ∨ ¬p) ∧ (p ∨ y) ∧ (r ∨ ¬y) ∧ (b ∨ ¬y) Clearly, any interpretation satisfying the resulting formula (if applicable) corresponds to a solution of the underlying game instance. 3 A variant Here is a variant of the game based on alternative rules : the player removes one token at a time and can either remove a square or a round token of any color. The game ends when each box contains exactly one token. The player wins if and only if all the tokens of each color have the same shape. SAT reduces to this variant in the same way as to the original game thanks to the following property. Proposition 1.
